title-group.article-title: Would a Flat-Rate Tax Stimulate Entrepreneurship in Germany? A Behavioural Microsimulation Analysis Allowing for Risk

abstract.p: When potential income tax reforms are debated, the suspected impact on entrepreneurship is often used as an argument in favour of or against a certain policy. Quantitative ex-ante evaluations of the effect of certain tax reform options on entrepreneurship are very rare, however. This paper estimates the ex-ante effects of the German tax reform 2000 and of two hypothetical flat-rate tax scenarios on entries into and exits out of self-employment based on a structural microsimulation model with econometrically estimated transition rates under risk. The simulation results indicate that flatter tax systems do not encourage people to choose self-employment, but rather discourage them from doing so. This is explained by the reduction of entrepreneurs' income risk through progressive taxation.

A business tax reform was launched simultaneously on 1 January 2001. Among other measures, it reduced the corporate income tax rate from 40 per cent for retained and 35 per cent for distributed profits to uniformly 25 per cent, introduced the half-income system for distributed dividends, and replaced the limitation of the top marginal personal income tax rate for tradesmen (§32c of EStG, income tax law) with a lump-sum credit of the local business tax deductible from the personal income tax liability.
The Council of Economic Advisers to the Ministry of Finance (2004) suggested a similar (but not revenue-neutral) flat tax with a basic allowance of €10,000 and a tax rate of 30 per cent.

Davies and Hoy (2002) demonstrated that revenue-neutral flat tax reforms with lower basic allowances than in the pre-reform graduated-rate tax schedule result in higher inequality than the pre- reform situation according to any inequality index. If a higher basic allowance is chosen, a certain revenue-neutral combination of the flat tax rate and the basic allowance exists that does not change a given inequality index - for example, the Gini coefficient - in comparison with the situation without the reform. This combination is found in scenario HH.

For further comparison, the self-employment rate was 13.4 per cent in the UK and 12.6 per cent in the Slovak Republic, which introduced a flat-rate tax of 19 per cent in 2004. The cross-country comparisons must be interpreted with caution, however, especially if not limited to Europe: for the US, the OECD reports a self-employment rate of only 7.5 per cent in 2005, which is due to a different treatment of incorporated self-employed, according to Blanchflower (2000). In contrast, Holtz-Eakin and Rosen (2005) found that the self-employment rate is higher in the US than in Germany, based on a comparison of the SOEP with a similar panel data set for the US, the Panel Study of Income Dynamics.

For the US, the corresponding shares of people working in micro enterprises (respectively, SMEs) were 21.5 per cent (49.1 per cent) in 2000. About 0.85 per cent of the self-employed in Germany were not covered by any health insurance in 2003 (Greß, Walendzik and Wasem, 2005). Since 1 January 2009, health insurance has been obligatory for all self-employed.

Mandatory pension insurance applies for self-employed teachers without employees, nurses, midwives, artists, writers, journalists, craftsmen (who may contract out after contributing for 18 years) and other less frequent groups.
The basic pension is also available for dependently employed people who wish to supplement their statutory pension insurance.
Parker (2003b) provided insights into the private and public pension wealth of older self-employed people in Great Britain.

A new option for people becoming self-employed, having been dependency employed, to stay in unemployment insurance upon application was introduced in February 2006 but is not relevant for this analysis as it was not available in 2005.

The prerequisites for private pension insurance basically ensure that the funds are not consumed before old age. For all taxpayers (independently of the status as a dependently employed or self-employed person), upper limits of the provisions deductible as special expenses exist and are modelled in the STSM.

The so-called 'Ich-AG' ('Me-Incorporation') programme, which came into effect in January 2003, was only available to the unemployed, so it is not relevant for this analysis. In August 2006, both the bridging allowance and 'Me-Incorporation' programmes were replaced by a single new start-up subsidy programme (Gründungszuschuss), which is only available to unemployed people receiving unemployment benefits, so again it is irrelevant for transitions between dependent employment and self- employment.

In the baseline scenario, the individuals observed in dependent employment have an hourly net wage annuity of €11.64 on average and would earn €14.53 if they were self-employed. Risk aversion may explain why they chose dependent employment nevertheless, because they would face a much higher variance annuity in self-employment than they do in dependent employment. The large variance predicted for the counterfactual state results from the estimated large influence of the selection on unobserved characteristics (for the detailed results, see Fossen (2007)). The self-employed would earn slightly more if they were dependently employed, and they would have a smaller income variance; apparently, non- pecuniary factors compensate them for this small disadvantage in earnings (cf. Hamilton, 2000). Money and risk alone obviously do not completely explain the phenomenon of self-employment. However, for the analysis of tax reforms, the partial effects of changes in net income and its variance are decisive, which this study could identify.

Notwithstanding, a large share of the population have lower net income annuities under the flat tax than under the progressive tax. Especially for younger people with a still low, but rising, income, the current tax loss has a higher weight than the discounted gain in the future, so the annuity of their income stream decreases.
As the changes in the exit rates for the self-employed due to the flat tax scenarios are not significant, the sample of the self-employed is not discussed here further.

Having a self-employed father is used as an exclusion restriction as this characteristic is likely to have an impact on the probability of being self-employed (e.g. Dunn and Holtz-Eakin, 2000) but is not expected to have an influence on earnings after controlling for other relevant factors (cf. Taylor, 1996). In Germany, self-employed mothers were rare in the generation of most respondents' parents, so only self- employed fathers are used.

The number of children and marital status are well known to influence the decision to participate in the labour market and the choice between part-time and full-time work, especially for women, but are not expected to influence gross earnings (cf. Rees and Shah, 1986).

Income information for year t is obtained from retrospective questions in wave t+1 about a respondent's average monthly gross income in I, differentiated by income from dependent employment and self-employment. Income from self-employment (employment) is only averaged over months in which the respondent was actually self-employed (employed), so the information remains accurate if the respondent switched between employment states. Earnings levels rather than log earnings are used in the regression to avoid excluding people who report zero earnings, which is sometimes observed for the self- employed during temporary periods (cf. Hamilton, 2000).

Additionally, dummy variables for German nationality and physical handicap are added to the earnings equations, as these variables turn out to be important for the prediction of earnings. Year dummies are also included to account for the business cycle.

To obtain consistent predictions for the squared residuals, the predicted values from the log model must be exponentiated and multiplied by the expected value of exp(e,y). A consistent estimator for the expected value of exp(e,?) is obtained from a regression of the squared residuals on the exponentiated predicted values from the log model through the origin. This procedure does not require normality of e,j.

A11 monetary variables are deflated using the consumer price index (2001 = 100). The estimated real hourly gross incomes are converted into nominal yearly gross incomes before entering the STSM, and the resulting nominal yearly net incomes are converted back to real hourly net incomes afterwards, using the average number of hours worked in the sample of full-time working people.
